resource.chars:
They are described by Sais as S. spinosa and 
S. micronata, or rather as S. spinosa, Proles solitaria 
and S. spinosa, Proles pregaria. This however begs 
the question as to the truth of Chamisso’s theory and 
I shall therefore prefer to name the two forms I 
observed simply Salpa A & Salpa B.
At Cape York these two forms were always 
obtained together and only these. They were 
of about the same size but so totally distinct 
in <s>form<\s> appearance that had they belonged to any other 
genus they would have been justly regarded 
as separate species.
Salpa A (P.I fig 1) The body is gelatinous transparent 
and colourless except the nucleus (i) which has a 
deep reddish brown tint. It has a general square 
prismatic shape and is abruptly truncated and 
somewhat convex at each extremity. The posterior 
extremity is provided with eight hornlike processes,
which project backwards. Two of these are short 
and hook-like, placed one before the other in the 
median line at the posterior part of the superior surface.
On the upper part of the lateral surfaces there is 
on each side a short process. From about midway 
between the upper and lower edges of this surface 
a long, conical, process curves upwards and 
backwards. These processes are distinguished from the others by <s>having <\s> containing a cæcal process of the system 
of sinuses in their base (y).
Close to the lower edge of the lateral surfaces there 
is another short process like the uppermost one.
The respiratory apertures are wide and 
provided with <s>the <\s> valvular lips. The posterior (z) is 
narrower and has the valvular lip more marked
